text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Right-wing union SEK blames left-wing union PEO for the failure of the unions to establish a common line on proposals to change the cost of living allowance system.
- Briton gets 15 years for killing his wife.
- Unions plan to complain at the employment of Greek workers at Paphos hotels while Cypriots remain without work.
- Another "crying icon" is reported, this time at a church in Achna situated in the United Nations-controlled buffer zone.

- Representatives of the Thanos Club hotels admit they violated terms of their permit by adding a fourth floor on a hotel under construction in Paphos. The firm belongs to the family of the foreign minister, Alecos Michaelides.
- The United Nations is expected to announce "goodwill gestures" next week by the Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides to help improve the climate for talks.
- Confrontation marks a parliamentary debate between government and opposition deputies over the hotel being constructed by the foreign minister's family.
